item.title: Man, 64, killed and firefighter injured in blaze at NYC house: officials
item.description:
A 64-year-old man was killed and a firefighter hurt when a fire ripped through a Queens home early Friday, officials said.Â 

The man was discovered inside the two-story private house on 46th Street near 39th Avenue in Sunnyside Gardens, where the first floor became engulfed in flames just before 3 a.m., according to the FDNY and NYPD.

He was pronounced dead at the scene and his name was not immediately released.

One firefighter was also taken to Weill Cornell Medical Center with minor injuries, fire officials said.Â 

A dozen FDNY units, including 60 fire and EMS personnel, responded to the blaze, which was extinguished just after 4 a.m.

The cause remains under investigation by the FDNYâs fire marshal, officials said.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: Meet the 70-year-old playwright who won the cityâs first-ever all-age, all-gender beauty pageant
item.description:
Sheâs the King of Brooklyn.

A 70-year-old playwright and self-proclaimed âdrag kingâ took home the crown last week at the Big Appleâs first-ever all-ages, all-gender beauty pageant â a title she won thanks to a singing performance that left judges teary-eyed.

Denise âMistahâ Coles was crowned the inaugural âBrooklyn Community Kitchen Monarch,â an honor she hopes to share with older citizens across the five boroughs.

âBeing a person of an older age, we have to be understood. Weâre not being put out to pasture because weâre a little bit older. I have a lot to offer,â said Coles, of Ozone Park.

The ground-breaking pageant was hosted by, and in honor of, Brooklyn Community Kitchen, a three-decade-old soup kitchen in Greenpoint.

âI knew it was going to be a ball, that we were going to have fun. I really did not expect to be winning anything, but I did,â said Coles, who has written and executed four off-Broadway plays.

Coles was one of eleven contestants for the pageant, which organizers said followed a formal format, including interview segments, evening attire and a talent portion.

Contenders sang, danced and even rode a fake bull â but Coles stole the show when she took the stage as a âdrag king,â which is a female performer dressed in a masculine outfit. Herâs even included a painted-on beard.

She wowed the crowd as she belted out âI Know Where Iâve Been,â the iconic song about racial equality from the âHairsprayâ soundtrack.

âIâve been singing it for years and will continue to sing it until I donât have to sing it anymore,â Coles said.

âIn the beginning I have [trousers] and everything else, and by the end of the song that I sing, Iâm in a red dress, red wig, lipstick.

âAnd I got a standing ovation, believe it or not.â

At that moment, the entire room knew Coles had cinched the crown â except Coles herself.

The songstress was apparently blind to the stage presence that oozed out of her â she earned the nickname âMistahâ after gaining a reputation for her infamous leadership working behind the curtain. Ironically, it had nothing to do with her drag king performances.

âMistah is a really special person who had a real vitality to them, and that really came through,â Thomas Tomczak, Brooklyn Community Kitchenâs board secretary, told The Post.

The inaugural event was completely sold out, and donations for Brooklyn Community Kitchen continued to pour in well after the lights on the stage were dimmed.

âThe intention was always to support this really great cause and have some fun, and we were able to do that with this group of people that we were so lucky to find,â said Simone Tetteh, the groupâs board president.

âIt was a real example of community at work.â

As for Coles, she plans to continue singing and performing for as long as possible, now with a crown on her head, the beauty queen said.

âI think you [should] look at life like itâs yours and be happy. You gotta let things go â people hang on to stuff that bothers them. To me, that eats away at you inside. Donât do that.â
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.title: Trump administration yanks $400M in grants, contracts from Columbia University over antisemitism on campus
item.description:
WASHINGTON â The Trump administration yanked roughly $400 million in grants and contracts from Columbia University on Friday, citing the schoolâs noncompliance with anti-discrimination laws.

The funding cancellation comes after months of antisemitic harassment and intimidation on the Morningside Heights campus â with pro-Hamas slogans proclaimed by demonstrators and the NYPD eventually being called in to restore order last April.

âSince October 7, Jewish students have faced relentless violence, intimidation, and anti-Semitic harassment on their campuses â only to be ignored by those who are supposed to protect them,â said Secretary of Education Linda McMahon in a statement.

âUniversities must comply with all federal antidiscrimination laws if they are going to receive federal funding. For too long, Columbia has abandoned that obligation to Jewish students studying on its campus. Today, we demonstrate to Columbia and other universities that we will not tolerate their appalling inaction any longer.â

A joint task force to combat antisemitism â which includes the Departments of Justice, Health and Human Services, Education and the General Services Administration â announced the withdrawal of US taxpayersâ money from the school, noting that âadditional cancellations are expected to follow.â
item.author: Josh Christenson

item.title: Long Island caretaker arrested in caught-on-video abuse of woman, 83
item.description:
A Long Island caretaker was arrested this week in the heinous abuse of an 83-year-old woman in her care that was caught on video, police said Friday.Â 

A guardian of the victim had placed a camera in the elderly womanâs Woodmere home after finding bruises on her late last month, Nassau County Police said.

The surveillance equipment allegedly captured the victimâs caretaker, Merlyn Fredericks, 36, yanking the helpless old woman harshly and beating her in her face and body, authorities said.

The guardian notified police, and Fredericks was arrested Thursday and charged with felony assault, as well as endangering the welfare of the senior, cops said.Â 

Her arraignment was expected Friday at First District Court in Hempstead.Â 

Meanwhile, the Nassau County Police Department is urging anyone who may have been a victim of a similar incident to call Crime Stoppers at 1-800-244-TIPS or dial 911.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: New York Cityâs Peter Pan men: Theyâre fun, flirty â and gone by morning
item.description:
Itâs 8:30 a.m., and Iâve woken up in my best friendâs Chelsea apartment to my phone buzzing with notifications.

Iâm only 24 hours into my latest New York jaunt, and already Iâve got three men hitting me up for a date.

Who is she?!

I should start by stating: this is not normal for me. Was I swiping madly on the apps, trying to lock down some fun? Nope. I met them IRL (for the boomers: in real life) one night at a bar called Do Not Disturb.

Clearly, they did not take note â and I am very much here for it. This speakeasy, nestled in the heart of the West Village, was my first stop â straight off a long flight â to meet girlfriends for a long-overdue catch-up.

I expected sordid tales of our latest dating escapades and a few laughs over delicious mac ânâ cheese and martinis. What I didnât expect was for myself and three girlfriends to be surrounded by men at 10 p.m. in a dimly lit bar, perfect for those jetlagged eyes, being offered drinks left, right and center.

Now, let me be clear â I am not a supermodel. In fact, Iâm not even in my 20s. So watching this all play out did wonders for my self-esteem.

But what I quickly realized over the next 10 days? New York men are absolute pros at making you feel like the hottest woman alive.

Just donât expect them to stick around.

Yes, I had stumbled upon a city full of Peter Pans â men who refuse to grow up. Theyâre charming, bold and wildly confident. Unlike the hesitant, âwait-three-days-to-textâ guys in Sydney or London, these men will walk right up to you in a bar, flash a dazzling smile (usually brightened by those fancy teeth-whitening strips youâre all obsessed with here), and lock in plans before youâve even exchanged names.

Not in a sleazy, âHey, what are you ladies drinking?â way, though: more of a confident, âIâm-here-to-shoot-my-shotâ way that was, well, intoxicating.

The first guy I met was sitting at the bar alone, and Iâm not going to lie â it was the beard that got me. Oh, how I love a man with a beard. I blame âYellowstone.â

As I was pointing him out to a friend, we locked eyes, and he motioned for me to come over.

Bold. I loved it.

I sauntered over â OK, I was one martini down, so my saunter could have been interpreted a few ways â and we were off and firing. He bought me a Negroni, told me about his job, asked about mine, and within minutes, we were exchanging Instagram handles before I was pulled toward a group of finance bros chatting up my girlfriends.

Not to brag, but I laid on the Aussie accent thick. And it worked.

Before the night was over, I had also swapped Insta handles (the new âCan I get your number?â) with the bartender and a guy who, after a quick Google search, I discovered had a small part in the original âGossip Girlâ series.

Oh, New York, you really bring out an array of men.

The following night, I was invited to an Aussie pub launch party downtown, and Iâm ashamed to say I wasted a perfectly good New York night making out with an Aussie bloke.

But never fear â I made up for it later that week.

âGossip Girlâ Guy (or 3Gs, as he shall henceforth be referred to) texted me the next night, inviting me to Soho House. But my hangover from said Aussie pub experience was so brutal, I declined a perfectly good invite.

Shame, Jana â shame!

However, I did indeed go on a fun date with Bearded Man. We decided to try a cocktail at every bar we came across in NoHo â and he gave me his finest sales pitch on why he was a âgreat guyâ in between showing me pictures from his phone of him dancing behind the DJâs deck at some Hamptons party and sitting in a box at a pro basketball game.

Ding a ling a ling!

Whatâs that sound? Oh, just the alarm bells of a Peter Pan.

Nevertheless, I didnât mind because I was having a fun time. It ended with some frisky action toward the close of the night and a beautiful DM the next morning.

But a second date? Please. This PP has a full diary â and, no doubt, a full roster.Â 

And then came The Fireman.

Yes, an actual fireman. While strolling through Soho, I spotted a classic New York fire station and went to take a picture. Just as I lifted my phone, a very chiseled firefighter appeared, grinned, and asked, âWant me to pose for you?â

Um. Yes, sir.

Not only did he strike a pose, but he then smoothly asked for my number and slid into my texts minutes later with a cheeky follow-up message and a picture of himself âon the job.â

I think itâs safe to assume this was not the first time heâd used that pickup line.

At this point, I started to think New York might just be the horniest city on the planet.

And I had the proof already sitting in my past. If you read my previous column, youâll remember Mr. Big â a charismatic New Yorker with a booming voice and an even bigger ego who swept me off my feet last time I was in town.

Without giving away his identity, heâs gone viral multiple times for ranting on podcasts about what men look for in a partner, waxing lyrical about romance, and how men should properly court a woman.

His confidence was off the charts and, oh, how I fell for it. His ability to back it up? Well â¦

As I wrote in my previous piece, the man had me intrigued. He kept in touch between my New York trips, promising me the full fantasy â a romantic weekend at his house upstate, a fancy upscale dinner, the works.

And what did I get upon arrival this time? Ghosted.

Yes, I got New Yorked by a very cleverly disguised Peter Pan. Oh, I walked right into that trap.

But, you see, theyâre not all bad guys. (OK, Mr. Big was a bit of a d â â k). Theyâre just Peter Pans who have no interest in growing up.

It makes sense when you think about it. New York is famous for attracting men who thrive on the thrill of the chase, whether in business or romance. And when it comes to dating, why settle when thereâs a fresh rotation of women at every bar?

Men are drawn to this city to make it big. Theyâre toiling away their working hours making that money â and theyâre out-of-hours having a jolly good time spending it.Â 

This theory was backed up the following Sunday as I was catching up with girlfriends over brunch, filling them in on my debaucherous week. They knew all too well about these Peter Pans and shared their own experiences with charmers who are fun but fleeting.

Now, not to boast, but my girlfriends are hot. Theyâve got great jobs, great faces and killer attitudes. In any other city, theyâd be snapped up in a heartbeat.

But in New York? Like most single women in their 30s, theyâre on Struggle Street, left dealing with men who are hunters who get bored once theyâve caught their prey.

I quickly realized my friends were right. Locking in a first date? Easy. A second date? Well, whereâs the fun in that?

So, would I recommend falling for a New York Peter Pan? Absolutely not.

But would I recommend letting one flirt with you at a bar, take you on a whirlwind adventure, and leave you with a cheeky text to reminisce over later?

One hundred percent.Â 

Just make sure youâre âdoing it for the plotâ and not âdoing it for the ring.âÂ 

Fly free, Peter Pans, fly free â¦
item.author: Jana Hocking

item.title: Long Island girls basketball rivals battle for Nassau County title
item.description:
They wouldnât want it any other way.

Two Nassau girls basketball rivals will duke it out at noon Saturday at Farmingdale State College in a true David vs. Goliath county championship.

Itâs the first title appearance for the fourth-seeded Plainview-Old Bethpage Hawks as they go up against the No. 2 seed, nearby rival and defending champion Syosset Braves.

âThatâs just a great game to say you won,â Hawks star guard and forward Emma Heaney told The Post of the upcoming contest.

âItâs a respectable team, weâre a respectable team, and itâs just going to be a great championship,â added the Lafayette-bound senior, who will take the court for the Leopards next winter.

Hawks 12th-year head coach Nick Tomasulo knows this opportunity has been a long time coming.

âThis program, when I took it over, was winning like two or three games a year,â he said.

âSlowly but surely over the last four years, making the semifinals became a bit of the standard. But with Emma and the seniors, they raised that standard and can really make something special happen now.â

The coach added that their 61-49 loss to Syosset in January became what the squad needed to finish the year strong.

âIt was after that loss that we vowed to each other, âThis is it. There should be no other losses. We should be celebrating at the end,â â he said of his team that won its final seven games to finish with a 17-5 record.

âNow weâre here, and itâs exciting.â

Settling the score with 19-3 Syosset will be no easy task, as Braves head coach Michael Ferreira intentionally scheduled several high-competition city schools throughout the season to up his playersâ grit.

âThis team really wants to win,â he said. âBut we donât talk about back-to-back a lot â¦ this group just really wants to make their own unique history.â

A little south in Plainview, theyâre focusing on playing their own game rather than the sizable task at hand.

âWeâre just all chasing that feeling [of victory] and taking it play by play,â Heaney said. âThatâs really helped us prepare for Saturday.â
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: Port Washington boys hoops team has eyes on ending 78-year Nassau County title drought
item.description:
These Vikings have weathered the storm for 78 years.

The last time the Port Washington boys basketball team won it all in Nassau County was 1947.

However, you donât have to scan a lifetime to see impressive hoops at the high school, as the top-seeded Vikings are making their third straight trip to the AAA title game after losing the previous two to Baldwin.

The Norse-named bunch will have its work cut out in Saturdayâs championship when taking on a very tough second-seeded East Meadow juggernaut at Farmingdale State College.

For head coach Sean Dooley, snapping the drought would be a âcool anecdoteâ and âadd to the story,â but this finale is all about the recent unfinished business.

âWeâre just trying to get to that point where weâre the winning team,â he told The Post, adding his players donât want to be known as the bunch who didnât finally get over the proverbial hurdle.

For a slew of seniors who have played varsity since sophomore year, coming so close the past two seasons has mentally felt like 78 years.

âIt would be nice to finally get it done now,â 12th-grade shooting guard Kenny Daly told The Post. âItâs so fresh in everybodyâs head.â

The boys are buzzing

The 18-4 team is ready for whatever comes its way this weekend. The stoked squad was revved during a Wednesday practice in which even players on the sideline were at a fever pitch as they rooted on teammates.

Practicing and playing with fervor is something Dooley, Nassauâs AAA-2 coach of the year and 2023 New York state coach of the year, stresses big-time.

âEnergy is something that you can control,â senior point guard Kenny Reyes said. âItâs much more funâ to play the game with spirit, he added.

Daly recalled a âslow startâ against Chaminade during which Dooley called timeout to simply psych up the boys and snap the early funk.

âWe came out and dominated the rest of the game,â Daly said of the 66-46 victory.

Dooley proudly says he ânever has to ask for energy,â and team camaraderie is a dream come true.

âItâs 15 guys that all get along and support each other, and every guy is rooting for somebody elseâs success,â he said.

From bus rides after wins to deli trips after Saturday morning practice, Reyes said the current group includes some of his closest friends â and that several recent alumni will be in the stands to pull for the team this weekend.

âWinning it for this whole town and our teammates who graduated, after all the support they have showed us the past three years, that would be the best moment for me,â forward Ryan Shanahan said.

However, thereâs a much more significant motivator for the gang larger than the past 78 â or two â years.

âWe want to win because we want to get back together the next day,â Dooley said of hopefully moving on next to the Long Island championship.

âThe next time we lose is the last time we get together â and we donât want to stop getting together.â

By air or by sea

Adding to the championship intrigue, 19-3 East Meadow has won out since losing to Port Washington, 55-44, in December. In January, the Jets won a rematch, which was also Port Washingtonâs most current loss, by a score of 57-47.

They, too, are chasing unprecedented glory as the 68-year-old school has never won a title, according to head coach Tom Rottkamp.

He said the team is a genuine âband of brothers,â with six seniors who have played together since sixth grade.

Their focus remains on sound fundamentals rather than the storylines surrounding the winner-take-all game, according to the coach.

âIt doesnât matter who you play,â said Rottkamp, who added there is mutual respect between the two schools. âYouâve got to win the game.â

And Port Washington is certainly not taking the Jets for granted, either.

âTheyâre a really good team,â Shanahan said. âWe know weâre gonna have to battle a full 32 minutes on Saturday.â
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: Long Island track star Zariel Macchia will compete in state championship after court rules in her favor
item.description:
She sidestepped catastrophe.

Zariel Macchia, the star William Floyd runner and future Olympic hopeful who was banned from the upcoming winter season state championship because of an obscure technicality, will race after all, a court ruled Thursday.

âI was relieved at first,â Macchia, who spent the past two days in legal proceedings after her family sued the New York State Public High School Athletic Association, told The Post.

The senior was initially barred at the end of February after violating an NYSPHSAA âcollege ruleâ about competing against college athletes when running in the Boston University David Hemery Valentine Invitational with collegiate athletes.

Had she or the same competitors not been running under their school names, there would have been no issue, her father, Peter Macchia, previously explained.

Judge Christopher Modelewski ruled the NYSPHSAA was ârequired to permitâ Macchia to partake in this weekendâs events on Staten Island, court papers obtained by The Post show.

Their argument in court was that Macchia âwill suffer irreparable harm which cannot be remediedâ by losing her chance to run in her last winter state meet.

Along with 1,000- and 3,000-meter races, she is in the 1,500-meter leg of an âall-starâ relay with some of the best New York runners around.Â 

âIâm definitely ready to run,â she said. âMy teammates were very, very excited,â she said.

Throughout the hassle, Macchia said the running community kept her moving through the tribulations with an outcry of support â even from those she lost touch with.

âJust knowing that I have so many people who want to see me do well, it is definitely a lot of motivation to compete well on Saturday,â Macchia said before joining her dad on a ritualistic good luck training run at the beach where she won her first ever race at as a middle schooler.

In a statement provided to The Post, the NYSPHSAA said it will respect the decision.

âThe NYSPHSAA acknowledges and respects the courtâs decision. We remain committed to the development and enforcement of rules and regulations established by our member schools to support and enhance the participation of over 450,000 student-athletes,â Dr. Robert Zayas, the NYSPHSAA executive director, said.

William Floyd School District spokesman James Montalto told Patch the district was âpleasedâ with the ruling and that it was âexcitedâ sheâll have the chance to race or a state championship.Â 

âShe is a phenomenal student and athlete, both in the classroom and on the track, and an even better person,â Montalto said. âWe look forward to all of the top competitors from across the state competing this weekend. she worked so hard for this and deserves the opportunity.â

The ruling comes amid an uproar a short distance away in New Jersey, where another scholastic athlete has been battling against the state agency that governs high school sports.Â 

Earlier this week, New Jersey wrestler Anthony Knox won decisive bouts against the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association in court allowing him to compete for his fourth state wrestling title.Â 

Knoxâs situation is starkly different from Macchiaâs because his suspension had been handed down initially due to a physical altercation that occurred during a regional tournament in February.Â 

Closer to Macchia, six Northport high school wrestlers had won an appeal early last month that allowed them to compete in their leagueâs tournament after they had been considered ineligible because participated in too many matches during the regular season.
item.author: Alex Mitchell, Christian Arnold

item.title: Hochul admin offers another deal to striking NY prison workers, bypassing union
item.description:
Gov. Kathy Hochulâs administration is bypassing the correction officers union, offering illegally striking guards at over 30 New York prisons another deal if they return to work Friday.

The state proposed a new deal â without the unionâs sign-off â in a desparate attempt to get the prisons fully staffed after the guards walked off the job on Feb. 17 over unsafe working conditions.

Department of Corrections and Community Supervision Commissioner Daniel Martuscello told reporters Thursday the new terms would establish a committee âfocused on safetyâ that would address concerns about the HALT law governing solitary confinement in prisons. Correction officers have argued the law limits their ability to control unruly inmates and safely do their job.

The potential agreement would also include many of the same provisions included in the first deal offered by the state and accepted by the union last week, including:

  • A 90-day suspension of some aspects of the solitary confinement law
  • 2.5 times overtime pay for 30 days after officers return to work
  • Adjourning legal proceedings against participants in the illegal strike
  • Reimplementation of health insurance for those whoâd been terminated
  • No discipline for striking workers

âThey deserve it. Weâve heard them. We need them. They play an important role in public safety,â Martuscello said of the correction workers.

The proposal is being offered to the guards without the support of the leadership of the correction union, the New York State Correctional Officers and Police Benevolent Association or NYSCOPBA.

Martuscello said the unionâs head, Chris Summers, gave him a verbal agreement that he would sign a deal, but that never happened.

âUnfortunately, this evening, President Summers and his executive board have refused to sign the Memorandum of Understanding, once again failing his members,â he said.

The union shot back that the deal wasnât up to par for its members.

âThis agreement does not represent the best interests of our membership,â NYSCOPBA spokesperson James Miller wrote in a statement to reporters earlier Thursday.

âAt this time, NYSCOPBA will not be signing this agreement,â Miller added.Â 

The rift between the unionâs leadership and its members has been on full display for weeks, with several officers telling The Post they donât trust their bargaining unit to represent them.

The unionâs executive vice president Matt Keough said as much Wednesday, Spectrum News reported.

âOur union membership has no faith in us right now,â Keough said.

Despite the lack of a legally binding agreement, Martuscello is offering a verbal commitment of his own.

âThese terms outlined, that my employees asked for, will be upheld and we will follow this to the letter for those individuals that return to duty tomorrow,â he said.

The wildcat strike, now on its 18th day, has thrown the state prison system into chaos and forced the Hochul administation to call in thousands of National Guard troops to man the detention faciltities.
item.author: Vaughn Golden

item.title: Missing NYC woman, 26, found dead in suitcase off Yonkers highway, ex-boyfriend arrested: sources
item.description:
A missing woman who planned on moving out of an apartment she shared with her ex-boyfriend was found stuffed in a suitcase in Yonkers Thursday morning, according to sources and her family.Â 

Pamela Alcantara, 26, was last seen in her Fordham Heights building in the Bronx on Sunday before mysteriously disappearing, cops said.Â 

Alcantara last spoke to her mother on FaceTime early Sunday morning and said she was set to head to a church service but never showed up, her family toldÂ News 12.

Surveillance footage obtained by the outlet shows her walking into the elevator but never leaving the building.Â 

Her desperate family plastered her photos outside the Morris Avenue and East 182 Street apartment and prayed for her safe return.Â 

Instead, her body was tragically discovered by police inside luggage off the Saw Mill River Parkway near Yonkers Avenue and Palmer Road in Yonkers around 9:50 a.m., according to sources.Â 

Her kin said Alcantara lived on the fifth floor with her former lover and was going to change apartments without him.Â 

Sources said the ex was arrested after a license plate reader caught his car near where her body was discovered.Â 

Charges were pending against him Thursday night.Â 

Alcantaraâs family was left grief-stricken following the gruesome discovery.Â 

âWe are all devastated because this should have never happened,â a relative toldÂ News12.Â 

âShe was only 26 years old and had her whole life ahead of her.â
item.author: Joe Marino, Amanda Woods, Steven Vago

item.title: House GOPers ask RFK-run agency if Andrew Cuomoâs COVID nursing home order broke safety rules
item.description:
House Republicans from New York are asking federal health agencies overseen by Robert Kennedy Jr. to rule on whether ex-Gov. Andrew Cuomo violated federal policy by sending elderly patients to nursing homes during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The congress members want Kennedyâs department to weigh in on whether Cuomoâs controversial March 25, 2020 order telling such facilities to accept recovering or âstabilized â COVID patients matched federal guidelines during the early pandemic.

âFive years ago, over 15,000 vulnerable New Yorkers died in nursing homes because of a reckless directive that forced COVID-positive patients into ill-prepared nursing home facilities after kicking them out of hospitalsâ Rep. Mike Lawler, the Hudson Valley congressman who drafted the letter, told The Post.

The March 6 letter was co-signed by GOP Reps Nicole Malliotakis, Nick Langworthy, Claudia Tenney, Nick LaLota and Andrew Garbarino.

âIâm demanding the CDC [Centers for Disease Control] and CMS [Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services] tell us the truth: Did Cuomoâs order follow federal guidelines, or did he defy them? Families of our constituents deserve answers, not excuses,â Lawler said.

The congress members noted that a house subcommitteeâs GOP majority report said the policy was âinconsistentâ with federal guidance â and that even a Democratic minority report said the edict âarguably contradicted federal CMS guidance.â

The House GOP members also asked why Cuomo, who was previously married to Kennedyâs sister, Kerry, would have scrapped the policy less than two months after it went into effect if it met guidelines.

The revised May 10, 2020 Cuomo policy forbade hospitals from releasing patients unless they tested negative for COVID-19 and barred hospitals from discharging a patient to a nursing home unless the operator certified he could take care of the patient.

Rich AzzopardiÂ cited a US Department of Justice watchdog report into leaks to the media about the agencyâs investigations into pandemic-related nursing home deaths that concluded the disclosures were partisan hits on Democrats and aimed at impacting the 2020 election.

âIt is also indisputable that the Inspector General investigated this issue and found that the Department of Justice corruptly used its power to go after Governor Cuomo and other Democratic governors over COVID in nursing homes for purely political purposes,â he said.

âIt also concluded that New Yorkâs nursing home policy was consistent with federal guidance, that a dozen states â Democratic and Republican â had similar protocols, and that those states had worse infection and death rates than New York. The attorney general and an independent review ordered by New York State concluded the same.â

Civil court cases involving this nursing home issue were dismissed and three separate DOJ probes, as well as one done by the Manhattan district attorneyâs office, were closed after concluding no laws were broken and there was no evidence of wrongdoing, Azzopardi said.

The Cuomo spokesman also claimed âno credible study has ever linked nursing home admissions guidance to an increase in deaths, but rather to community spread that brought COVID into nursing homes months before the US government was even aware it was here.â

A few independent studies claimed the March 25, 2020 nursing home directive, during the six weeks it was in effect,Â did cause additionalÂ deaths of nursing home residents.

Kennedy, the CDC and CMS had no immediate comment.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Mental patient escapes from New York hospital, cops warn locals âdo not approach himâ
item.description:
A mental patient is on the loose after he made a dash for freedom from anÂ Orange County hospital Thursday afternoon and cops warned the public to stay away from the escapee.

Christopher Morgan fled from the Garnet Health Medical Center in Middletown around 2:40 p.m., according to the New York State Police.Â 

Surveillance footage provided by troopers captured Morgan sprinting in the hospitalâs hallwayÂ during his escape.Â 

He was last seen wearing a long white jacket, police said.Â 

Authorities warned eagle-eyed locals to stay away from him.Â 

âIf you see Morgan, do not approach him,â cops said.Â 

Anyone with information should call State Police Middletown at (845) 344-5300.Â 

New York State Police did not say why he was in custody.
item.author: Steven Vago

item.title: Grinning maniac thought he was âHitler reincarnated,â made twisted promise before threats to shoot up NYC synagogue: prosecutors
item.description:
A Utah man accused of threatening to shoot up a Manhattan synagogue boasted that he was âHitler reincarnatedâ and made a twisted pledge to kill Jews, Manhattan prosecutors revealed Thursday.

Luis Ramirez, 23, allegedly threatened to kill âas many Jews as I killed in [World War II]â in a series of unhinged X posts where he threatened a massacre at the Central Synagogue on Lexington Avenue, prosecutors said as he was arraigned on terrorism and hate crime charges.

âThe defendant made terroristic threats that he was Adolf Hitler reincarnated,â Assistant District Attorney David Stuart said.

Ramirez â who flashed a sinister grin as he entered the court â was ordered held without bail and directed to undergo a psychological exam.

Ramirez was extradited from New Jersey after his Feb. 14 arrest by Port Authority cops as he was trying to cross into Manhattan through the Lincoln Tunnel.

No weapons were found inside his car when cops stopped him before crossing into Manhattan, sources said.

Prosecutors said Ramirez showed signs of paranoia and delusions while awaiting extradition to Manhattan â where he made references to himself with âbeing different biblical charactersâ in recorded prison calls.

Ramirez was discharged from military officer cadet training school in Virginia for psychological reasons, Stuart said.

Those delusions were enough for prosecutors to ask Manhattan Judge Julieta Lozano to order a mental health evaluation in addition to remanding Ramirez, which was granted by the judge.

Ramirezâs attorney, Sergio De La Pava of the New York County Defender Services, said that he felt a mental health exam was an appropriate measure for Ramirez after speaking with him and his family.

Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg, who attended the arraignment, said outside that courtroom that his office wouldnât tolerate hate crimes of antisemitism.

âHe is now charged with significant terrorism and hate crimes charges and was remanded into custody,â Bragg said.

âAny form of antisemitism is despicable, and I want Manhattanâs Jewish community to know we are remaining extremely vigilant.â

Ramirez faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted of making a terroristic threat as a hate crime.

Heâs due back in court on March 20.
item.author: Kyle Schnitzer

item.title: Ex-LI inspector general wonât face charges following probe into $2M cybersecurity contract: DA
item.description:
A former Oyster Bay inspector general who resigned due to allegations he attempted to funnel $2 million to his own company will not face any criminal charges after a lengthy investigation, prosecutors said.

Brian Noone has been under investigation by the Nassau County District Attorneyâs office for months â but the DA announced Tuesday that it dropped the probe for lack of evidence.

âAfter a lengthy and thorough investigation of the allegations, NCDA determined that there was insufficient evidence to support criminal charges in this matter,â Nicole Turso, a spokesperson for the DAâs office told The Post.

Noone, who was appointed as the communityâs first inspector general in 2019, was in charge of the townâs contracting process for roughly four years.

In June 2023, he resigned over allegations that his private business had ties to a vendor he was urging the town to sign a multi-million dollar cybersecurity contract with.

Once these ties were uncovered, officials raised alarms over their concerns about possible corruption and a potential conflict of interest.

Noone was immediately removed from his contract oversight duties, but a review by the townâs ethics board eventually cleared him of any wrongdoing, before the DA stepped in.

After Nooneâs resignation, former state Supreme Court Justice Angelo Delligatti was hired to handle the contract vetting but more recently, a team of town attorneys were running the show.

However, critics including Democrats and lawyers, raised concerns with the approach of letting the municipalityâs own attorneys fulfill the duties of the inspector general.

They argue that the job should be filled by someone who is independent from the administration to prevent any potential future corruption or conflicts of interest.

Now, officials like Republican and Oyster Bay Supervisor Joseph Saladino, say they are now committed to filling the role of inspector general permanently.

In an attempt to attract a larger pool of candidates, Saladino eliminated a requirement that the official must have three years of experience âas a supervisor of high-level public or quasi-public sector staffâ and is implementing operational changes to how the role is approached.

âWe expanded the role and clarified the investigative powers, and now we broadened the investigative requirements to attract a larger pool of candidates,â Saladino said.

Oyster Bay is now attempting to recoup from yet another political scandal. In recent years, the community has been plagued with several other controversies â including the conviction of former Supervisor John Venditto on corruption charges in 2019.

Former planning and development commissioner, Frederick Ippolito, also found himself in hot water when he pleaded guilty to tax evasion in 2016 over consulting fees he accepted while working for the local government.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: NYC remains a sanctuary city â as ânothing has changedâ despite Mayor Adams floating policy rollback, officials say
item.description:
Adams administration officials insisted Thursday that sanctuary city laws are still being followed â telling lawmakers that ânothing has changedâ despite Mayor Eric Adamsâ floating a potential rollback of the migrant-friendly policies.

âNo sanctuary laws and policies have changed,â Mayorâs Office of Immigrant Affairs Commissioner Manuel Castro assured members of the City Council during a hearing.

âIn our communities there is going to be a great amount of debate, perhaps even confusion, misinformation and so on,â Castro said. âBut we want to make sure that people know that no sanctuary city policies have changed and the direction to city agencies and offices continues to be that we follow our sanctuary city laws and policies.â

Councilmember Alexa AvilÃ©s, chair of the Committee on Immigration, accused Adams of sowing the âconfusionâ about the 40-year-old policies.

âWhat is clear is there is an awful lot of confusion about what to do which has been precipitated by the executive,â AvilÃ©s said. âThe problem seems to be with the mayor who does not understand.â

Castro assured AvilÃ©s his office has not proposed any changes to the cityâs sanctuary laws.

Adams hasÂ repeatedly suggestedÂ the city should change its longstanding sanctuary policies to increase cooperation with US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).

The mayor dared progressives to âcancelâ him in December when he announced he supported deporting migrants from New York City who have been charged with crimes â a shift from his past stance ofÂ waiting for convictions before shipping offÂ immigrant criminals.

Hizzoner appeared with President Trumpâs âborder czarâ Tom Homan on Fox and Friends last monthÂ promising he would reopen the ICE office on Rikers Island and allow city officials to collaborate with ICE on civil enforcement.Â 

But under questioning from council members, immigration officials in the mayorâs office said they had never seen any executive order draft that would accomplish the mayorâs goals.Â 

âThe mayor seems to be operating in explicit conflict with our local laws by saying ICE is going to be showing up at Rikers Island,â Councilmember Lincoln Restler said.

âWe donât have any information,â Castro replied. âMOIA has not been part of any of these conversations to change these laws.â

Molly Schaeffer, director of the cityâs Office of Asylum Seeker Operations, saidÂ she has not been consulted on any such executive order either.

A city council spokesperson said after the hearing that a proposal to make changes to the cityâs sanctuary laws is under review with the corporation counsel.

The spokesperson noted that changing most of the existing laws would have to go through the City Council.

But a provision in local law would allow the mayor to put an ICE office on Rikers Island through an executive order.

Restler said he found it âdeeply disrespectfulâ that city officials would show up to the hearing without any information on the mayorâs potential executive order.

âThe mayor has been sowing confusion and creating immense fear in our communities,â Restler said.

âThe mayor by leaning in to this mass deportation agenda of the Trump administration and embracing it and expressing it on TV his desire to bring it to New York City, despite our proud 40 year history of sanctuary city laws, is deeply disturbing,â Restler said.Â
item.author: Haley Brown

item.title: Eric Adams slams latecomer mayoral rivals Andrew Cuomo, Adrienne Adams â while insisting heâs ânot a quitterâ
item.description:
Mayor Eric Adams slammed latecomer Democratic election rivals Adrienne Adams and Andrew Cuomo Thursday for running âshadow campaignsâ capitalizing on his woes â while defiantly insisting heâs not going to drop out.

Hizzoner defended his own apparently largely nonexistent campaign during an unrelated press conference near Washington Square Park, arguing his rock-bottom poll numbers and continuing corruption case chaos donât spell re-election doom.

âIâm not a quitter, Iâm a New Yorker,â he said. âWe never surrender, never give up. This game is so far from over.â

The defiant message came on the heels of Cuomo, the former governor, and City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams both entering the already crowded Democratic primary race in the past week.

The mayor, who is of no relation to Adrienne Adams, accused the Council speaker and Cuomo of safely hiding in the shadows while he took hits on the front lines.

âThey were running shadow campaigns,â he said. âThey were not being scrutinized, they were not being questioned. You didnât know what their positions were.â

Adams â whose job approval rating hit a record-low 20% for a New York City mayor in a recent poll â contended that Cuomo, the speaker and the other candidates are running on his agenda.

âNow everyone is trying to shift and know that my winning solution of turning around the city, from COVID to crime, to jobs to the economy â everyone is now sounding like Eric Adams,â he said.

Cuomo announced his long-rumored candidacy Saturday, casting himself as New York Cityâs savior.

He entered the race as the instant front runner â a stunning reversal of fortune from 2021, when he resigned in disgrace as governor amid a swirl of sexual harassment accusations. He has consistently denied the accusations.

Adrienne Adams officially entered the race Wednesday. Sheâll hold a kick-off rally Saturday.

For his part, the mayor has shied away from campaigning as his criminal case drags out closer to the June primary.

Those close to Adams had hoped for a quick resolution with the new Trump administration, butÂ the backlash over how Department of Justice officials handled the dismissal â especially allowing it to be brought back at any time â forced the judge to delay even considering tossing the case till mid-March.

Adams has defended his absence from the campaign trail, contending heâs now an incumbent and doesnât need to raise his profile.

âI know how to overcome hurdles, I know it so well,â he said. âThe worst thing I can do is surrender to a lie. And I will never do that.â

Cuomo spokesman Rich Azzopardi said: âThey know we New York is in crisis and Governor Cuomo has the experience and the expertise to help save it.â

The speakerâs campaign didnât respond to a request for comment.

â Additional reporting by Amanda Woods
item.author: Georgett Roberts, Craig McCarthy, Matt Troutman

item.title: NYC aims to reclaim Washington Square Park from drug pushers, vagrants in latest quality-of-life push
item.description:
Mayor Eric Adams on Monday launched a new joint âcommunity coalitionâ with the NYPD to battle rampant drug use and vagrancy at troubled Washington Square Park and Greenwich Village.

Flanked by Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg and local civic leaders, Adams said 13 city agencies will team up with civil leaders to keep tabs on goings on at the 10-acre Lower Manhattan park â with the announcement coming on the heels of Police Commissioner Jessica Tischâs call for a new quality of life initiative.

âLast year, the city began to address the persistent public drug use, homelessness, and quality of life concerns in response to community complaints in Washington Square Park,â Adams said. âI remember we came out to the walk-through in the park, and it was not the imagination of community residents.

âIt was for real,â Hizzoner said. âThe drug use was there, people were using the park for their public toilet facilities and other problems that were really evident. And we saw the need to expand to the surrounding area, including to the West 4th Street subway station.â

The effort is part of Adamsâ âCommunity Link,â which teams officials with New Yorkers to tackle neighborhood woes and concerns.

Washington Square Park seems an obvious target for the effort â the 15-year-old urban green space has been plagued with crime, homelessness and unrest in recent years.

âWhen we think about Washington Square Park â¦ you think about the vibrancy of that area, artists, students, local businesses all coming together,â Bragg told reporters. âAnd then you see the real challenges there today, and itâs heartbreaking. But this is the recipe.â

In July, several brawls broke out at the park following the cityâs annual Pride Parade.

In April, an NYU administrator was randomly slugged while walking in the park in what cops classified as a hate crime, and in 2023 a homeless man was charged with stabbing another vagrant to death there.

Drug sales have also run rampant at the park, with pushers even masquerading as artists to peddle their goods, while others sold psychedelic mushrooms out of makeshift stalls.

Adams said the new community effort will team city agencies with local residents and civic groups to patrol the park with NYPD backup to identify and shut down criminal activity and unrest.

The multi-agency coalition will meet twice a month to stay on top of things, he said.

The move coincides with Tischâs quality of life announcement last week.

The effort, which has been likened to the NYPDâs onetime âbroken windows policingâ approach, would target open drug use, aggressive panhandling, public urination and other crimes both in the subway system and in the streets of the Big Apple, she said.
item.author: Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: 4 muggers bash man, 40, with hammer, punch boy, 16, in vicious attack inside NYC pool hall: cops
item.description:
A four-member mugging crew bashed a 40-year-old man with a hammer and slugged a 16-year-old boy during a vicious attack inside a Queens pool hall, cops said Thursday.Â 

The suspects barged into the Tian Yi pool hall on Union Street near Northern Boulevard in Flushing minutes before 10 p.m. Feb. 22 and demanded that the two victims get on the floor, police said.Â 

The brutes then brandished a hammer and struck the older man on the head before snatching about $1,000 from his jacket pocket, authorities said.Â 

They then punched the teen victim in the face and pushed him down to the ground, cops said.Â 

The older victim was taken to New York Presbyterian Queens Hospital, where he was listed in stable condition, while the teen was treated at the scene for minor injuries, police said.Â 

It is unclear whether the wounded pair worked at the pool hall.

The group of young men â seen in surveillance grabs released by the NYPD early Thursday â fled, heading east on Northern Boulevard, cops said.Â 

The first attacker, described as having a light complexion and slim build, was last seen wearing a black jacket, black pants, eyeglasses and black shoes.

The second suspect is also described as having a light complexion and slim build and was wearing glasses, a black hooded sweatshirt, gold jacket, black pants and black boots.

The third assailant, who also has a light complexion and slim build, was last seen wearing a black jacket with white fur on the hood, dark blue jeans and black boots.

The fourth fiend has a dark complexion and slim build and was last seen wearing a black jacket and black shirt, cops said.Â 

Anyone with information on the violent crime is asked to call the NYPDâs Crime Stoppers Hotline at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477) or for Spanish, 1-888-57-PISTA (74782).Â 

The public can also submit their tips by logging onto the Crime Stoppers website at https://crimestoppers.nypdonline.org/, or on X @NYPDTips.
item.author: Amanda Woods
